div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.
Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called

p.hi: Nature's Skin Food

div.p: and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: AMERICA AND RUSSIA.
div.p: We reprint the following from a leading article in the "New York Times" : If our territory adjoined the territory of Russia, if the United States stood geographically, let us say, in the relation- of Germany or Austria to the Russian Empire, it can hardly be doubted that we should long ago have been compelled by considerations of our own peace and security to remonstrate with the Government of the Czar against the prolongation of hopeless civil disorder in his dominions. Were that our position, with the Russians as our neighbours, it would be impossible that the sympathy and the humane impulses of our people should not be stirred by the intolerable sufferings of the Czar's subjects in their struggle to secure the right to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. Although we are something like half a world away from the scene of this disheartening conflict, our interests are very real, very immediate, and with the lapse of time they may compel us to such action as we might already have taken were we numbered among the European Powers.

The mere suggestion of American interference or of any foreign interference with the domestic affairs of a great European Power would be received with astonishment in every Continental chancellery. But the idea of such an intervention was not viewed with astonishment, hut with practically universal approval, when Emperor Leopold and the King of

div.head: P & O
div.p: WEEKLY MAIL and PASSENGER SEVICES

Prussia in 1791 signed the Declaration of Pilnitz, by which they agreed to join with other Princes to re-establish the authority of Louis XVI, and to furnish him with the means of putting down the French Revolution and maintaining "a Government suitable to the interests of the Throne and of the people" That was intervention to strangle liberty and hold up the hands of her destroyer. The Declaration of Pilnitz was intended to strengthen the Coalition against the French Revolution, and, later on, every European Power save Sweden, Denmark, Switzerland, Venice, and Turkey did join with armed force or other aid in the attempt to restore the French throne. The self-interest of kings was held to justify the union of all to relieve the distress of one.

Has time moved with such a leaden foot that after more than a hundred years free peoples must be forbidden to consider the question whether it may not be their duty and their privilege to come to the relief of millions upon millions of their brethren helplessly and almost hopelessly striving to throw off the yoke of an oppression incomparably more tormenting than the burdens imposed upon the French people by the privileges of the crown and the nobles ? What are the preconceived notions of propriety that are held to preclude the consideration of concerted influence to put an end to the present "hell upon earth" in Russia ? Is it the notion of mere bigness ? Is it because men shrink from the idea of coercing a sovereign of such state and dignity? That argument will not bear examination. The coercion actually in progress is exercised by a little group of men upon 110 millions of people. It is that huge constraint that should give us concern, not the minor matter of hindering a few hundred or a few thousand bigoted and unenlightened reactionaries in the execution of their mediaeval and inhuman designs. On that theory France was too big a nation to be interfered with when the Coalition sought to put down the Revolutionists. The reply of the people of Paris was to throw the head of their King at the feet of Europe in defiance. "What is impossible to twenty-five millions of men ?" said Carnot; and they proved it was at least impossible for Europe to crush them. They held their own. The Czar and his reactionary bureaucrats are not twenty- five millions. The conditions are reversed. It is impossible that they should hold out against the protest and the pressure of the civilised Powers.

Our interest in the restoration of civil order and the erection of liberal institutions in Russia is the interest of every great nation. Our rights of trade and intercourse are measurably abridged so long as this great Empire is given over to strife and practically to anarchy. Moreover, the weakness of the Czar s Government and the incredible cruelty of his administration in many parts of the empire are sending to our shores every year a flood of enforced and therefore undesirable immigrants.

Although the senseless appeal of the Czar for the election of a mute and dumb herd of representatives to the new Duma—an appeal that reflects a darkened mind guided by evil counsel—forces foreign observers to the conclusion that the fires of revolt in Russia will be quenched by no acts of liberal concession from the autocracy, and although through want of experience and organisation, and, above all, through the failure of competent leadership, the Russian people seem scarcely more capable than the Cuban people of effecting unaided their emancipation, we are not the opinion that foreign intervention in the domestic affairs of that Empire is a matter of the immediate future, or that for the present it will even come under practical consideration, The point upon which we wish to insist is that the principle of ultimate intervention is not excluded by history, by international law, or by human reason human probability. The interests, the peace, and the security of the great Powers of the world, and, reinforcing those considerations, sympathy and humanity, the horror of cruelties long continued, the indignation kindled by the spectacle of a downtrodden people baffled in every attempt to win their freedom, shot down for no worse crime than expressing a desire for liberty, terrorised at every turn by the prison and the bayonet, must sooner or later lead to a union of sentiment and concert of action that will end the Russian hell upon earth. It cannot go on for ever. The time will come and it ought not to be far distant, when civilisation will say to the Czar, You shall not make your palace the sepulchre of a people's hopes, nor continue to flood our realms with your bleeding subjects fleeing from your assassin soldiery.

div.head: Land Survey.
div.p: Twenty-four new land surveyors have been engaged for the Sharkieh and Behera.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin records a death in hospital and a recovery at Alexandria.

div.head: Fatal Fall.
div.p: A native workman fell from a building in Nubar Pasha-street yesterday and was killed.

div.head: French Garden.
div.p: This evening, Messrs. Bazzarini and Williams will meet in a final wrestling bout, after the latter's recent defeat.

div.head: Mafish Nafas !
div.p: The Ismailia quarter of Cairo was in darkness for several hours on Wednesday night owing to a short circuit. Sanganeib Lighthouses. Of the total credit of L.E. 19,000 for the construction of the Sanganeib Lighthouse only L.E. 447 has been spent up to date.

div.head: Serum Tubes.
div.p: All tubes of serum which have been deteriorated by loss of humidity are to be sent by the sanitary inspectors to the central depôt of the Sanitary Administration.

div.head: Robbers Sentenced.
div.p: The Berberee who committed the robbery at the residence of Baron von Oppenheim has been condemned to two years' penal servitude, and his wife to six months for complicity.

div.head: Buried Alive.
div.p: Two days ago a native workman was buried alive under a heap of earth which fell on him in a pit at the Paulino hills, where he was digging. His dead body has now been extricated and buried.

div.head: Sultan's Fete.
div.p: The Officer Commanding the British Army of Occupation has accepted the invitation of the Fête Committee to the Accession Day celebrations, and has authorised a British military band to be in attendence in the Esbekieh Gardens.

div.head: Case of Rabies.
div.p: A case of suspected rabies occurred on Wednesday afternoon at Ghezireh, where a dog bit a policeman and two other people. The onbashi valiantly slew the animal and in the struggle no less valiantly wounded himself with his own sword bayonet.

div.head: Arabic MSS. for British Museum.
div.p: From the British Museum return, which has just been published, we learn that among the Oriental acquisitions are seveval rare Arabic MSS. of the twelfth, thirteenth, and fourteenth centuries, and an extensive collection of Mohamedan traditions.

div.head: Protecting Beccaficoes.
div.p: All the police kisms of Alexandria have received orders, in virtue of the regulations in force, to arrest vendors of beccaficoes and seize their merchandise. A reward of P.T. 10 is given to the policemen for each arrest made when it is followed by the seizure of the birds.

div.head: Mex Casino.
div.p: On the occasion of the Sultan's Accession Day, to-morrow, a number of balloons will be sent up at the Casino, and a concert will be given by the Giuseppe Garibaldi band and the orchestra of the establishment. Tramcars will run to Mex all night, in connection with the ball given by the Reunion des Families Society.

div.head: Mouleds.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has given permission for the following mouleds to be held : Djelal el Siouti, Assioat, from 25th inst. to 5th September; Abdel Rahman el-Mouli, from 26th inst to 20th September; Sayid Mohamed Faris, Minieh, from 9th to 19th September, and Sayid Ali Shamroun, Minieh, from 28th inst to 12th September.

div.head: Railway Administration.
div.p: The Ministry of Finance has replied to an application made to it by the State Railways in favour of day workmen being granted leave of absence as in the case of employes in Government service. The Ministry says that it cannot legally satisfy such a demand, but that the Administration may draw up a draft law which will be favourably considered, after it has received the approval of the Railway Board.

div.head: Village Murder.
div.p: A dead body was found at Tawael, Akhmin district, a few days ago in an advanced state of putrefaction. The head and face were smashed in and there was a gun-shot wound in the back. The autopsy held showed that death was due to the gun-shot wound and that the disfigurement of the head and face was done afterwards in order to render identification impossible, but the murdered man was recognised by his clothes and a mark on the right ear. His name is Selim Farag el Dib.

div.head: A Prince and his Land.
div.p: Prince Youssef Kamel Bey has given up some plots of land—1,000 feddans in area— which he purchased recently of General Djelaleddin Pasha, to Princess Fatimeh Hanem, daughter of the late Khedive Ismail Pasha who paid the price of the same, amounting to L.E. 170,000. This property had been bequeathed to Djelaleddin Pasha by the late Princess Ismet, his wife. Princess Fatimeh, mother of the late Princess, being anxious to restore her daughter's property, claimed the same by right of pre-emption, and Prince Kamel has agreed to allow it to change hands and to receive the price of the land.

div.head: MURDER AT SHOUBRA.
FRENCHMAN SUSPECTED OF CRIME.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent sends us the following particulars of the murder discovered on Wednesday morning Shoubra :—

The body of the unfortunate cafedji, Andoni Scopelitis, who was a native of the Greek Archipelago, was first discovered in the sakieh on Rifai Bey's estate by some children, who were horrified to find the body floating about on the surface as the water was being disturbed by the water wheel.
The police had little difficulty in identifying the corpse, for Scopelitis and his little cafe were local landmarks on the Rod El Farag tramway.

A serious wound on the head and a rope round the neck sufficed to show that violence had been committed, and the deceased being a Hellenic subject, the consulate was immediately communicated with. A janissary of the consulate opened the preliminary investigations, the result of which showed that the deceased had last been seen in company of a young Frenchman who was a frequenter of the café. This was at one o'clock on Monday afternoon. Since then the cafedji had been missing, and the café was closed at night by the neighbours, the disappearance of Scopelitis being notified to the police. Of course suspicion at once fell on P., the young Frenchman, and accordingly a representative of the French Consul went to the Maison Ciccolani, where he lived, to enquire, only to find that he had fled to Alexandria, where I understand be has been arrested.

P. does not enjoy a very good reputation, he was often in low company, and owed the cafedji money for various orgies. To this the father of the accused testifies by declaring that Scopelitis had come to him on the Monday to get nine fraucs due to him by his prodigal son. P.'s father occupies a position of some standing in the French society of Cairo and is an official of the Mixed Courts.

The sakieh in which the corpse was found was in the middle of a field of maize, 120 yards from the palace lately acquired by M. Gianaclis. A narrow pathway winds through the maize from the property to the sakieh.
Scopelitis, who was sixty years old, leaves a wife and married daughter at Leros, in the Aegean.

We are informed by M. Rikaki, acting Hellenic Diplomatic Agent, that no further information is at present obtainable in regard to the crime, and that the preliminary enquiry is being continued by the Parquet.

div.head: QUARANTINE IN CYPRUS.
div.p: A telegram from Cyprus states that five days' quarantine has been imposed on arrivals from Alexandria, and a medical visit on arrivals from other Egyptian ports.
Arrivals from Adalia undergo 48 hours' quarantine.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: According to the "Minbar," the Khedive will spend Ramadan in Alexandria and go to Cairo for Beyram.

div.head: STREET REGULATIONS.
div.p: Excellent measures in order to prevent encumberment and the constant accidents that occur at night have been prescribed by the Cairo police with regard to trolly carts. The following is the text of a circular which has just been issued : —
1. On no account will two-wheeled trolly carts (whether drawn by horse, mule, or donkey) be allowed to carry planks, poles for scaffolding or farahs, iron rails, etc, longer than 4 metres in length.
2. Any such poles or rails over 4 metres, must be carried on 4 wheeled trolly carts.
3. Should they however be over 5 metres, two carts most be employed, the first being a four or two wheeled trolly, and the second . a two wheeled trolly towed behind.
4. Poles, rails, etc., must always be transported lengthwise on the carts, and not crosswise or at angles.
5. All poles over 5 metres in length will be transported between dawn and midday.

6. Any cart found transporting planks, rails, or poles, over 5 metres not according to above rules, will be taken to the nearest caracol. If within the prescribed hours, it will be unloaded, and again reloaded according to the instructions. If not within the prescribed hours it will be kept outside the caracol till the fixed time when the carter will be ordered to load according to the orders.
In every instance however the numbers and permits will be withdrawn from the carters and sent to the Traffic Office.
No. 5 came into force yesterday ; the remainder will be enforced after 10 days, to permit of the merchants arranging their carts.

div.head: NEW STEAMSHIP LINE.
ALEXANDRIA TO BERLIN IN 4 DAYS.
div.p: Mr. Otto Sterzing, the company's agent in Cairo, informs us that the Norddeutscher Lloyd, Bremen, in connection with the Serviciul Maritim Roman, will start on October 18 next the new express service between Constanza, Constantinople, Smyrna, and Alexandria. The S.S. Imperatul Trajan will make the first voyage. The King and Queen of Roumania will be present at the inauguration of this line.

The fleet for this service consists, besides the before mentioned vessel, of the S.S. Romania and two new twin-screw steamers of about 5000 reg. tons and 9,000 h. p., with an average speed of 19 knots an hour; all being magnificent steamers, fitted with the latest improvements.

The departures from Constanza take place immediately after the arrival of the Orient Express train de luxe from Paris and London of the International Sleeping Car Company and the express train from Berlin via Cracow Czernowitz, and Burdujeni. Passengers from Egypt will have the same facilities of connection when reaching Constanza.

The steamers leave Constanza every Thursday evening, Constantinople Friday evening, Smyrna Saturday evening, and arrive at Alexandria early on Monday morning. On their return voyage they leave Alexandria on Friday night, reaching Costanza on the following Tuesday.

Passengers will now have an opportunity of making a round trip from Egypt viâ, Smyrna and Constantinople to Constanza and returning by one of the Norddeutscher Lloyd steamers from Hamburg, Bremen, Antwerp, Southampton (London), Gibraltar, Marseilles, Genoa, Naples, to Port Said or Alexandria, or vice versâ, on combined return tickets.

This new service, which connects more closely the eastern part of the European Continent with Egypt, will no doubt be of great importance for both passengers and the mail, the distance between Berlin and Alexandria being shortened to a little over four days.

div.head: THE OSMANIEH.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Line's new steamer, the S.S. Osmanieh, arrived at Alexandria at 5 o'clock this morning on her maiden voyage. The vessel left Southampton at 2.30 p.m. on the 22nd inst, and passed Gibraltar on Saturday evening. She had six hours' stop owing to fog off the coast of Portugal, and experienced very bad weather in the Bay of Biscay. She arrived at Malta last Tuesday morning and stopped 14 hours there for coaling. Very bad weather prevailed between Malta and Alexandria ; indeed, had it not been for the rough weather, she could easily, have got into Alexandria yesterday.
Invitations are being sent out for a private view of the vessel on Thursday next. The public will be admitted to see the vessel on Saturday and Sunday.

div.head: LATE PRINCE MOHAMED IBRAHIM.
div.p: H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly is expected to arrive at Alexandria on Sunday next, in order to represent H.H. the Khedive at the funeral of Prince Mohamed Ibrahim. The Prince's mortal remains, which will arrive here on the 4th prox., will be accompanied by T. H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha Halim Princess Saliha, widow of the deceased, and Princess Shneikar, his sister. On arrival here the body will be placed in a special train and conveyed to Cairo. At 4 p.m. the cortège will proceed from Cairo station to the cemetery of the Khedivial Family.
The Orwa-el-Woska Society of Alexandria will send all its pupils to the quay to meet the Portugal.

The funeral ceremonies and the customary mourning receptions will be held in the ex- residence of Kahil Pasha, situated near the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, which the Daira of the late Prince set aside a few days ago for this purpose. The necessary preparations are being made in the building.
The Mehkemeh Sharieh will shortly appoint guardians to the children of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim ; but the appointment will not take effect before the return of H.H. the Khedive.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD.
div.p: On enquiry at the Cairo offices of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., this morning we were informed that no information had been received as to the rumoured resignation of Mr. Constantine Meimarachi. The Cairo offices had received a business telegram yesterday from London and it contained no allusion whatsoever to any such resignation. We publish some comments on the subject from Cairo news papers in page 4 of to-day's issue.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY
div.p: By kind permission of Major C. J. L. Davidson, D. S. O., commanding, and officers, 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will perform the following programme in the Esbekieh Gardens from 9 to 11 p.m. on Saturday, 1st September, in honour of the anniversary of the Sultan's accession:—

div.head: THE UNREST IN EGYPT.
ANGLO-EGYPTIAN'S VIEWS.
div.p: "Anglo-Egyptian" writes to the "Times" : —

The troubles in Egypt have settled down for the time being, but the British public do not seem even now to realize how acute the crisis was at the time nor how near we were to a catastrophe. The danger is surmounted for the time being ; but the Pan Islamic movement is a force which mast always be taken into consideration in the future—a volcano of extreme power even when apparently quiescent. With political tension we may be sure that the religious element will be introduced, and the smallest cause would be enough to start an outbreak which would spread like a flame throughout the land. There would be no time to get troops from Malta or other places before an appalling amount of loss to life as well as to property had taken place There are, roughly, about one million Copts and a quarter of a million Europeans in the country, for whose safety, as well as for that of British subjects, Great Britain has assumed responsibility. The Mohamedans outnumber them ten to one ; in addition, there are many thousands of predatory Bedouins in the desert whose sheikhs live in Cairo and are in constant touch with them. Our garrison even when reinforced will be slender, and must necessarily be localized in one or two centres.

Well might an American say last December —a time at which in some villages the names of those to be killed were written down on paper—"That if England was unable or unwilling to protect the lives entrusted to her care it was time other nations helped or did it for her."

That the British Government has recognized the existence of the danger is evident from the grave words of Sir E. Grey and by the increase of the garrison. But the troops are quartered in towns, and do not come in contact with village life. What is required is the strengthening of the Administration by the introduction of British influence into those branches which come in contact with the people, such as the police. This might be done by enlisting time- expired non-commissioned officers of good character, tact, and common-sense to serve in the police. The mere presence of these men in the villages would serve to check crime, and they should be of inestimable service to the Government, as they would gradually get into close touch with the natives and might get to know of any organized rising in preparation in spite of Mohamedan secretiveness.

Non-commissioned officers of this kind are to be got. I have met them. The work is so important that they should be taken on probation, so that only those proved to be suitable would be retained. Such men should never be under the orders of natives, but responsible to the British inspectors only; and, as the natives are adepts in the art of getting up cases against each other, these special service men should not be left to their mercy but should be strongly supported by the central Administration. As they would undoubtedly incur at the first the fanatical hostility of the lawless element, it would probably be advisable to send them out to the villages in twos.
As to the cost, the Egyptians themselves have rendered this step necessary and they would have to pay.
The effect on the country I believe, from a long and intimate acquaintance with the natives, could not fail to be good and might render extreme measures unnecessary.

div.head: FRANCE AND PAN-ISLAMISM.
div.p: Discussing the probable effects of the Pan- Islamic agitation on the future of France's African possessions, the "Temps" says that there is at present no sign that Egyptian nationalism has made any converts in Algeria or Tunis. The reason no doubt is that the French have taken root in the soil and established themselves permanently, whereas in Egypt British occupation is purely military and administrative, and the prospect of getting rid of it has no inherent impossibility.

Although Pan Islamism does not now seem likely to create trouble for France in Algeria or Tunis, the situation is different in the Sahara and the Sudan. The conception of a plot extending all over this vast territory is somewhat romantic, but the Djanet affair and the rebellion organised by the Marabouts at Zinder are warnings that ought not to be neglected. France evidently has adversaries who are ready to use Pan-Islamism as a weapon against her.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Perim (Westcott and Laurance Line) left Malta last Tuesday and is due here, viâ Tripoli, next Monday, with general cargo from Antwerp and London.
The S.S. Kaffir Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left London on the 29th inst., and is due at Alexandria on or about the 14th September.
The S.S. Trojan Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on the 29th inst., and is due at Alexandria on the 2nd September.

div.head: THE TABAH INCIDENT.
THE SULTAN'S REAL OBJECT.
div.p: Writing on the Tabah incident, the editor of the "Revue de Paris", Victor Bérard, summarises the history of the Sinaitic Peninsula from early times down to the evacuation of Tabah on May 11th last.

The recent action of Turkey on the Egyptian frontier, he says, is not an isolated incident. During the last year the policy of Abdul Hamid has been one of aggression towards all his neighbours, in fact he has not a single neighbour in Europe, Asia, or Africa that he has failed to provoke.

In reference to the evacuation, the writer wonders whether the Sultan only succumbed when he had tangible proof of the defection of the Kaiser, "the friend of the three hundred millions of Mussulmans." Germany is accused of having a hand in the incident, but it may be that the Sultan was too full of admiration for the Kaiser to note that with his friend prudence of action invariably belies boldness of speech.

The real cause of the incident, thinks the writer, was probably connected with the question of the construction of a railway to Medina and Mecca, and perhaps the Sultan imagined a Turkish railway to Tabah would be the best means to prevent the English from making a railway across Arabia. At all events, when England imputes the responsibility of the affair to German diplomacy alone, sufficient allowance is not made for the morbid imagination, alternating between depressing terror and wild fancy, which determines the conduct of Abdul Hamid.

In the "Revue des deux Mondes," René Pinon, who writes on the Tabah incident, recapitulates the events relating to the Sinaitic Penninsula, and studies the present question in connection with the efforts of Germany to establish economic and political power in the entire Empire of the Sultan. England, ever concerned with the defence of India, now sees a danger in Arabia, especially in the light of the Mussulman policy of Germany. The writer thinks that Germany has too much interest in the East not to realise that in the Tabah incident her future in the Ottoman Empire was in question, and that England as master of Egypt, and with a formidable navy, night easily become master of the Turkish Empire in Asia and the land routes between Constantinople and the Persian Gulf.

div.head: THE ANGLO EGYPTIAN MAILS.
div.p: In reference to the criticism published by "La Tribuna" of Rome on the subject of the mail arrangements at Brindisi, which we quoted in yesterday's issue, it is worth drawing attention to the great need that exists for doubling the line to that port. Nowadays, when Italy has become a first class Power, and the north of the country has developed a really amazing amount of commercial energy, the want of double lines on such a route of the Indian and Egyptian mail is keenly felt. This want the Government should now supply without delay, more especially as all the bridges on that line are wide enough for two pairs of metals, and there is only one tunnel the whole way, while land along the Adriatic Coast and in the taxoliere of Apulia is as cheap as when Juvenal said that you could buy a vast estate there for an old song. Thus, and thus alone, will Brindisi retain its classical and mediæval renown as the port of embarkation for the East; thus, and thus alone, will it be able to compete with its present rivals, Naples and Marseilles, and its future competitors, Constanza and the Piræus, the ultimate terminal of the Larissa Railway.

div.head: TRIESTE.
div.p: The new State line between Trieste and the valley of the Save, which has just been opened by the Hereditary Archduke, is but the first of a number of railways which will shortly open up the western parts of Austria to commerce, and will enormously increase the trade of Trieste. The Alpine districts, above all Carniola, Corinthia, Styria, and Upper Austria, will be placed within easier reach of the sea, and in consequence the cost of freight will be much reduced. It is hoped that a great industrial expansion will be the result, aided by the enormous water power available in the Alpine districts, and that the export of timber will be especially enhanced. When all the lines now under construction are finished, which should be in a little over two years' time, Trieste will tap the country lying north and north-west. Probably Southern Germany, and especially Bavaria, will make use of it as a port, while as another line will be open to Vienna, the commerce from Central Austria should feel an immense benefit. But Trieste will have to do its part if it wishes to profit largely by the new state of things. At present the harbour and docks are insufficient for any increase of trade and the shipping lines are too few. The Chairman of the Austrian Lloyd has recognised that something will have to be done if the probable passenger traffic to Alexandria is to be coped with, and if Austria does not not intend to be beaten on her ground by German shipowners, who are already preparing to take advantage of the new openings for business. But even more important than the building of fresh ships is the enlargement of the port of Trieste. Even as it is the trade of the town has been growing by millions, and if she wishes to profit by the new lines, and to hold her own with Genoa, Hamburg, end Bremen, she most at once set to work on the necessary improvements.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lady Campbell-Bannerman, whose death is announced in today's telegrams, was the daughter of the 1ate General Sir Charles Bruce, K.C.B. She married the present Premier in 1860.

When Mr. Haldane, Secretary for War, was summoned to Marienbad as Minister, in attendance upon the King he was to have opened a bazaar at Dunbar. His place was taken by Major-General Wingate, the Sirdar.
The Duke of the Abrizzi was to have returned from his expedition to the Mountains of the Moon by way of Gondokoro, Khartoum, and Cairo, but he has now decided to return to Europe by way of Mombasa.
Mr. Brunyate, Acting Judicial Adviser, attended the Council of Ministers at San Stefano yesterday in order to give his opinion as to the legislation for promoting cotton plantations from worms, etc.
H.E. Mustapha Pasha lbadi, Governor of Alexandria, is expected to arrive here on Tuesday next, on his return from Europe.

The marriage of Mr. Henry Brooke Greville, manager of the New Egyptian Company and formerly manager of the Cairo branch of the Bank of Egypt, son of the late Admiral Stapleton Greville, and. Miss Cecilia Hervey- Bathurst, eldest daughter of the late Colonel Sir Frederick Hervey-Bathurst, Grenadier Guards, took place last week at St. Peter's Church, Eaton-square. The clergy of St. Peter's performed the ceremony, and Sir Frederick Hervey-Bathurst, Grenadier Guards, gave his sister away. She was unattended by either bridesmaid or pages, and was married in a gown of soft white satin, the flounces on her skirt, her train, and her veil all being of fine antique Brussels lace, which her mother had worn at her own wedding. The Hon. Claud Yorke acted as best man. A reception was held by the Dowager Lady Hervey-Bathurst in Cornwall-gardens.
Mr. G. Foaden, secretary to the Khedivial Agricultural Society, arrived in Cairo on Wednesday evening on his return from Europe and resumed hit duties yesterday morning.
The suicide of a well-known Greek resident in London occurred last week, Mrs. Aglaia Coronio, the widow of a stockbroker of Holland Park.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit— within certain necessary limits— free discussion.

div.head: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: To THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, — Re crusade against immorality in Alexandria. It is believed various Consuls put their wits together and came to some agreement that seems none too manly but really cowardly. There could be no unfortunate women here or elsewhere if all men were self-respecting. It's proper that this class of women should be prevented from becoming over-bold, a nuisance and eye-sore to the public, and there is a vast improvement this way daring last few weeks, thanks to police activity. These women are now afraid to annoy or solicit. The men do the soliciting at present, and the great number of perfect brutes in human form that live on these women and tout for them, called by a name affectionately applied by natives to each other, are left un- noticed by the police ! Let the Consuls put their knowledge-boxes together again to consider if present methods are really efficacious. Why not abandon this unseemly, cowardly women chasing and arrest the army of male brutes that speak to, associate with, or do "business" for these pitiable women ? So long as these contemptible men can do as they please then just so long can these female wretches defy police efforts. Destroy their miserable trade by removing the cause of its existence and they most disappear in due course without troubling the authorities. Most of the touts, etc., are low-class Jews and Levantines, generally local subjects, so there need be no consular voice in the matter. Let the police clear off the boot-lace sellers, ticket vendors, not men, gambling "lucky-bag" men, and all such nuisances after 7 p.m. These people are message carriers and go-betweens; it takes no detective to find this out and much more. Any man alone in Alexandria desiring a quiet iced drink on a breezy spot al fresco can see all these abominations with half an eye. At many of the numerous places here where the public rendezvous these hot evenings a hundred arrests could be made on above lines. Before the third evening the police could have a holiday if they did their duty with reason, common-sense, and thoroughness, but interfering with a respectable lady because she happens to be momentarily alone is a direct invitation to crime, as her friends and relatives may be around ready to defend her against base insinuations on the part of a stupid policeman who could have no one's sympathy. Leave the women alone and arrest the blackguards.
Hoping you can find space for above few hints. — I am, etc.,
C. W. A. N.
Shillelagh Castle, Alexandria, August 29.

div.head: WALKER & MEIMARACHI LTD.
M. MEIMARACHI ET LE CONSEIL D'ADMINISTRATION
div.p: Le bruit ayant conru de la démission de M. C. Meimarachi, au sujet des démêlés entre lai et le Conseil d'Administration de la Walker and Meimarachi Co. Ltd., nous nous sommes adressés à la succursale de cette société à Alexandrie pour avoir des éclaircissements. Malheureusement, ces questions sont traitées directement entre l'administrateur-délégué et le board de Londres, ce qui laisse dans une complète ignorance l'administration locale.

Nous croyons cependant d'an certain intérêt de reproduire les appréciations, de la presse du Caire, où cet incident, après la récente démission de M. Montagu Sommers, a produit une certaine émotion, vu la grande notoriété de M. C. Meimarachi dont les hautes capacités sont assez connues.
Du Journal du Caire :

La nouvelle donnée par un confrère du matin sur les dissidences de l'Association Walker et Meimarachi sans pouvoir être pleinement confirmés ne sont pas dénués de fondement. D'après nos renseignements M. Maimarachi, actuellement à Paris, rue Lafayette, serait sar le point de donner sa démission d'associé de la maison Walker et Meimarachi dont il est l'administrateur délégué. Eu effet, à la suite des plans de construction des Grands Magasins, la Conseil d'Administration siégeant à Londres avait une première fois réduit considérablement le projet et obligé la Société à un première vente de terrains qui rapport» nu bénéfice moyen. Dernièrement, les nouveaux plans soumis an Conseil furent discutés à nouveau et encore réduits, ce que M. Meimarachi ne croit pas devoir accepter. Le Conseil d'Administration de Londres composé d'actionnaires an port de titres suffisant pour donner la qualité de membres du Conseil, ne semblant pas se rendre un compte exact des besoins de le Ville du Caire besoins absolument connus et appréciés de M. Meimarachi, dont la haute compétence dans les affaires lui a valu les meilleures relations dans notre Ville. Mais la décision, de M. Meimarachi, nous l'espérons, n'est pas irrévocable.
Du Progrès :

La baisse manifestée sur les actions Walker & Meimarachi est due au bruit d'après lequel M. Meimarachi serait fermement décidé à résigner ses fonctions d'administrateur délégué, à la suite de divergences de vues avec les administrateurs du board de Londres. Il serait à souhaiter queces Messieurs se rendant compte des hauts services que M. Meimarachi a rendus à la Société renoncent dans l'intérêt même des actionnaires à maintenir cet état de choses qui ne peut être que préjudiciable à tous les intérêts de la Maison.
De MM De Vries et Boutigny : —

Nous avons eu l'occasion de parler, il y a Quelque temps, de dissentiments graves qui s'étaient élevés entre le Board de Londres de la Walker and Meimarachi Ltd. et M. Constatin Meimarachi, administateur-délégué de cette Société en Egypte. Or, si nos informations sont exactes, M. Constantin Meimamarachi se serait va obligé de déclarer caté goriquement qu'il préférait se retirer si le Board de Londres persistait à vouloir lui imposer Deux personnages qui exerceraient con jointement avec lui les fonctions, d'administrateur-délégué. L'affaire est là, et c'est ce qui a fait courir ce matin en Bourse la rumeur que la retraite de M. Meimarachi peut, d'ores et déjà etre considérés comme une éventualité presque certains, sinon comme un fait accompli.

Eu dernière heure, nous avons pu appendre de la direction du Caire de la Walker and Meimarachi Co. Ltd. qu'elle n'a recu aucune information concernant la prétendue démission de M. Constatin Meimarachi. La dépeche qu'elle a recue hier de Londres ne contient meme aucune allusion à ce sujet.

div.head: BULETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui à midi et demie.)
Toute l'attention da marché s'est concentrée ce matin sur le Trust et le Comptoir.
Le Trust s'avanes à 1 7/16 et le Comptoir à 8 5/8 et 6 1/2 respectivement, en gain de 1 /32 sur les cours d'hier.
Une petite demande fait remonter l'Union Foncière de 6 à 6 1/16-1/8.
La National Bank monte également de 26 5/32 à 26 1/4 acheteurs.
Il y a eu quelques rares transactions en Agricole et Delta Land qui se maintiennent fermes aux cours antérieurs.
Aujourd'hui, dernier jour de la liquidation, tout s'est bien passé ; la cote a fait preuve d'une excellente tenue. Lundi prochain, c'est jour de paiement.

Nous apprenons que M. Périclès Glymenpoulo a décidé d'abandonner généreusement sa commission pour faciliter la fusion de l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Limited avec la Building Lands of Egypt Limited.
Sudan Government.
NOTICE.

Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them.This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in presence of an official or other reliable witness.
Change of Address

The Public are generally requested to take note that "The English Nursing Home," Cairo, has removed from its quarters at Bab-El-Louk to the House formerly occupied by Ibrahim Bey Cherif, Kasr-El-Nil Street, Cairo.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES. Le Caire, 30 Août.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a baissé lier de 1/8 à 87 3/4. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 3/4. La National Bank est demeurée également inchangée à 26 3/8, la Daira à 16 3/4 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4. L'Agricole seule à gagné 1/8 à 9 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien s'est tenue à son prix précédent, soit 751. La Banque d'Athènes a rétrogradé de 1 franc 141.

Ici, la série des séances calmes continue ; suivant tontes les apparences, elle est appelée à se prolonger quelque temps encore, sauf événements imprévus. L'inaction pourrait bien finir par s'aggraver quelqne peu du chef da resserrement monétaire que l'on appréhende pour le mois prochain et des réalisations qui péseraient alors sur les cours. Toutefois la cote est, pour l'instant, assez bien soutenue, en dépit de la liquidation de fin de mois, ce qui montre qu'il n'y a pas de positions surchargées.
La National Bank a débuté à 26 3/16 pour clôturer à 26 1/8-3/16. L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a progressé à 222-223. La Banque d'Athènes s'est alourdie à 141-142.
L'action Crédit Foncier a fléchi à 753-754 ; L'obligation à lots ancienne est remontée à 335-336. La Daïra Sanieh a fléchi à 16 5/8 et la Nile Land à 13 15/16.
L'action Immobilière a avancé à 388-389 ; poursaivant son mouvement ascensionnel, la part de fondateur a passé de 715 à 738.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a gagné 1/16 à 4 5/16-3/8. L'Union Foncière est revenue à 6 1/16-1/8. Les Allotments se sont raffermis à 3 7/16.
L'action Héliopolis a été traitée à 320 et la part de fondateur à 8 3/4. La part de dividende Ciments s'est inscrite à 17-18. Le Ramleh a été coté à 7 1/8.
Dans le groupe des valeure hôtelières, les Nungovich ont faibli à 17 5/16-3/8 Les Egyptian ont été négociés aux abords de 6 3/8. Les Upper Egypt ont été demandés à 4 13/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été ramenés à 8 5/16 et les Hooker à 0 15/16. La part de fondatear Estates a été moins bien tenue à 11 9/16-5/8. Les Oasis ont reculé à 1/32. Les Walker and Maimarachi sont restés à 0 11/16. Les Sucreries se sont raffermies à 23-24 francs.

Suivant des informations d'Alexandrie, on s'attendrait à ce qae l'assemblée extraordinaire le la Building Lands of Egypt Co., convo quée pour le 4 septembre prochain, ratifie la fusion de cette Société avec l'Egyptian Trust and Investment Ltd (Glymenopoulo).
C'est tout an moins sur cette rumeur, pro pagée en Bourse, que les actions da Trust se sont raffermies hier à £1 3/8. Par contre, les Building Lands out encore perdu 1/16 à £5 1 /8.
Nous extrayons d'une lettre de Paris, en date un 23 Août, les lignes suivantes:

"Au début du mois d'octobre prochain, un gros montant de traites émises par le Trésor russe, sous la garantie de la Banque de l'Etat, vient à échéance. Le gouvernement du Tsar pourra-t-il faire face de suite à ce paiement et, par le même coup, relever son crédit ou bien deyra-t-il demander des renouvellements à des conditions qui ne seront certes pas des plus avantageuses ?

"D'autre part, on rapporta qu'un groupe de banquiers à la fête desquels serait la grande maison Mendelssohn, aurait obtuna du gouvernement russe l'autorisation de fonder une Banque Nationals, avec un capital à émettre par actions, qui reprendrait la suite des affaires de la Banque de l'Etat avec certaines concessions. Ceci aurait-il rapport quelconque avec l'échéance prochaine des Bons, du Trésor ?"
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Il est rappelé aux détenteurs de parts de fondateur de la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux que l'échange des certificats provisoires en titres définitifs, se fait, depuis le 16 Août courant, dans, les bureaux de la Société, rue Madabegh.

D'une statistique , intéressante publiée à Londres, il ressort que les Compagnies d'assurance anglaises auraient eu à payer aux sinistrés de San Francisco la somme de £9,290,000. Ce chiffre doit, cependant tenir beaucoup de la conjecture, car il est bien des sinistrés dont le le compte n'est pas encore réglé; il y a beaucoup de contestations en suspens.

Il est à remarquer que presque toutes les Compagnies atteintes par la catastrophe ont résolu de prélever intégralement sur les réserves qu'elles ont en Angleterre les sommes qu'elles ont à verser pour la reconstruction de San Francisco et de laisser intactes celles qu'elles ont constituées aux Etats Unis.
Cela explique, les offres importantes de Consolidés et autres titres , similaires qui ont pesé depuis quelques, mois sur le marché de Londres.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier de "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" parais chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir ètre expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs ; les der nières statistiques jusqu'à la veil e de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la dlace et les copies des dépêchas officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication 1a construction de 2 égouts à fond perdu à Ibraoimieh et Bulkeley (Ramleh).
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. è midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Admiaistrateur de la Municipalité, avant le 4 Septembre 1906.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation, le même jour à 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter eu outre la mention "Soumission pour Construction de 2 égouts à Ibrahimieh et Bulkeley (Ramleh).

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture des offres et an pius tard le 4 Septembre prochain à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vice-Président,
(Signé) DR. SCHIESS.
Alexandrie, le 27 Août 1906. 28411-3-2

div.head:
MORE EARTHQUAKES IN CHILI.
INDESCRIBABLE PANIC.
EXTEND TO FRONTIER OF PERU.

div.p: Heavy earthquake shocks have been felt at Tacna and Arica, extending to the frontier of Peru, causing indescribable panic. The people are sleeping in the squares. (Reuter)
A Ukase prolongs the minor state of siege for a new period of 12 months and authorizes the issue of a loan of 50,000,000 roubles at 4 % in order to aid the famine-stricken. (R.)
A Ukase has been issued extending the state of siege for one year. M. Stolypin s daughter is getting better. (Havas)

The strikes at Santander and Bilbao are increasing in gravity. Fresh troops have been drafted to these centres and the military authorities are preparing to cope with the revolutionary movement. (Reuter)
An expedition, consisting of 450 men and two guns, under the command of a colonel has left Temassinin for the Oasis of Djanet. (Reuter)

It is understood that Japan and Korea have arranged to convert Chinsawen, guarding the entrance to the Straits of Tsushima, and Yeungheung, north of Gensau, into regular naval stations, Japan bearing the expense. (Reuter)
Mr. Haldane is here for the purpose of studying the military institutions. He will not attend the Silesian manoeuvres. (Reuter)
General Sir John French leaves to-day in order to attend the French manoeuvres. (R.)
Lady Campbell-Bannerman died here. King Edward has expressed his sympathy with the Premier. (Reuter)
Lady Campbell-Bannerman is dead. (Havas)

div.head: THE EASTERN MAIL SERVICES.
div.p: The "Times of India" (Bombay) says:-- "The new Australian mail contract opens up possibilities in the Far Eastern mail and passenger service that were scarcely anticipated when the agreement was announced. . . . It will naturally extend its ambitions to the much more lucrative Indian mail and passenger traffic. . . . It implies no criticism of the P. and O. to say that this will be a good thing for India. Competition is the essential stimulus to progress. It is astonishing how many more things even a great shipping Corporation can do, and how many more facilities they can offer, when there is a rival in the field. . . . If British shipowners are wise, they will also keep a very watchful eye on the entry of the Hamburg-American Company into the Persian Gulf. The Company has a splendid organisation and large resources ; if it is not to capture a considerable share of the Gulf trade those in possession will have to 'get a hustle on'."

div.head: BAD FOR BLONDES.
div.p: A physician is responsible for a statement which is at once novel and surprising. He declares that the chances of dark women obtaining husbands are to those of fair women in the proportion of three to two ; and that this conclusion is proved by statistics.— "Family Doctor."

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM IN EGYPT.
div.p: ("From the "Tribune.")

Whatever concerns the mysterious movement of unrest in Egypt must be to us a matter of profound interest, and the well-written article from a Frenchman resident in Egypt, which filled over three columns of yesterday's "Temps," would have claims on our attention even if his theme touched us less nearly. The writer is manifestly an able and a well informed man ; he is friendly to the English occupation, and not without sympathy for the natives, while he writes with a manifest desire to be rank and impartial. There is no doubt in his mind that the absence of gratitude in the Egyptian mind for the benefits of the English occupation, the present subdued disaffection, and the Denishwai affair itself are all the result, not only of fanaticism, but of an organized Pan-Islamic movement, and behind them he sees not only Turkish, but German influence. That is, of course, the view which Lord Cromer has put forward. When we find it shared by a competent French witness, who writes the opinion of many of his friends, we have no choice but to believe that it is the prevailing view among Europeans in Egypt. To criticize their diagnosis may seem at first sight presumptuous, and, indeed, there is every probability that they and they alone are likely to judge the situation correctly. And yet those who have had experience of small colonies isolated among an alien and not entirely friendly race know how ready they are to think collectively. Their isolation makes for unanimity ; they develop a somewhat exaggerated racial consciousness, and their views soon acquire the character of a loyalism, an orthodoxy which is above scepticism or criticism. The odd thing about this novel theory of fanaticism is that, by the confession of this writer, no one held it before the Denishwai affair. We are to suppose that a great movement had been silently working among the peasants for some years, that Mustapha Kamel Pasha and his popular Arabic paper "The Lewa" had been preaching fanaticism day by day unnoticed. Suddenly a few fellahs attack a party of English officers. European opinion—"even that of the eldest residents" — is, we are told, "stupefied." Men say to each other in clubs and messes that they "no longer recognize the fellah," and he has been "transformed." Somebody breathes the word "fanaticism," and this vague term is at once on every European's lip. That is the history of the recent panic. We are justified in drawing two conclusions. In the first place, a European opinion which admits it has been taken by; surprise cannot be in close touch with the natives. In the second place, if the Denishwa incident can be explained by some other theory we at a distance may without arrogance consider it.

Now as to the Denishwai affair this French witness is candid. He says frankly that the trial was "purely political," and that the execution "struck him with horror." But where is the evidence of fanaticism ? The villagers were provoked. Some officers had, as he puts it, the "folly" to shoot the domestic pigeons of the villagers—pigeons which they regard as one of their main sources of livelihood—they were trespassers, and they accidentally set a granary on fire and wounded a woman—indeed, the peasants believed they had killed her. Against such provocations human nature in any part of the world would revolt. Even in an English village sportsmen who behaved in this way would probably cause a riot—particularly if they were foreigners. But the European in Egypt replies, "Yes, but the fellah in the old day would stand anything, He might feel resentment, but he would not dare to show it" It was his daring in resenting his wrongs that struck Europeans "with stupefaction." What had given him this new courage ? The official answer is "Fanaticism," But even in this article we detect evidence of some other factors. Speaking of the prosperity of the native Press, the writer remarks that in the old days, "when life was cruel," the fellah lived with his eye on the ground, and was ignorant of everything even of the name of his Sovereign. Then came the English occupation. We lightened his taxes; we checked his oppressors; we stopped forced labour ; we gave him the security of honest courts. In a word, we relieved him from his old demoralization. We made him rich; we also made him free, "Riches," continues the writer, "have given him leisure, and leisure allows him to satisfy his curiosity" In a word, he reads newspapers, or more often has them read to him. But are "leisure" and "curiosity" at all likely to be the only fruits of riches and freedom ? We should say, on the contrary, that Lord Cromer had failed miserably if they were. He has we believe, succeeded better than he knows himself. He has made a man of the fellah He is no longer the cringing slave of the old days. He will no longer submit tamely to injury and injustice. Prosperity, an equal law, a mild rule, a general spread of education, and a wave of interest in the larger things of life— these are causes enough to explain his new attitude. It was a maxim of the old logicians to observe economy of causes. If gravitation will explain a given phenomenon, one does not invoke a special providence. If prosperity and liberty have made a free man of the fellah one does not require to assume fanaticism.

If there is anything in this reasoning— admittedly the mere speculation of an outsider who tries to criticize in coolness a letter from the spot written amid passion and in panic— the present direction of our policy is little short of a tragedy, The Egyptian is admittedly a new man. He reads, he discusses politics, he clamours for a more democratic system of education than Lord Cromer has given him (and here even this. French critic sympathizes with his demands) ; be asks us to give him a least some earnest of the self-government which Lord Dufferin promised a quarter of a century ago. Instead of realizing that his very mood of opposition, his intellectual awakening, and his personal independence are a tribute to our rule and a proof of its success, we take alarm, talk rather wildly of fanaticism, and embark on a policy of repression. There is no denying the fact that some Egyptians are turning towards Turkey because they despair of England. Even here, however, we think the evidence oddly meagre. Lord Cromer produced an anonymous letter from a Turkish priest. The contributor of the "Temps" declares that he could produce extracts from Mustapha Kamel's newspaper which would astonish Europe, but somehow he does, in point of fact, omit to produce them. But if the Egyptians are turning to Turkey, the moral is surely that we should be at pains to prove to them that their sober aspirations for liberty can be satisfied under a British protectorate. Pan-Islamism is not wholly an evil movement. It implies an awakening, a desire to be strong, and to march with the world, which we should admire unreservedly in the Japanese. Oddly enough, despite the partonage of the Sultan, it is allied in many of its adherents with a more or less genuine Liberalism. We are even told that the Sultan himself is meditating a return to Midhat Pasha's Constitution. Such a movement will be pro-German and anti-English if our attitude towards Egyptian aspirations is merely negative—it need not be directed against us or against the Christian world if we care to show that our sympathies can rise above a religious prejudice.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMIC SCARES.
div.p: The "Saturday Review" says :—"Extracts from Indian native papers fully bear out the view we have always put before our readers with regard to Pan Islamic scares, The gist of those articles which reached England this week may be roughly summed up as follows, The Sultan is the greatest of Mohamedan rulers, and we reverence him as such, but we do not intend to follow his bidding against that of our own Government. If the British Empire is at war with a Mohamedan Power we should regret it but should follow the British. This is quite satisfactory, but there will be nothing new in it to those who have followed our comments from time to time on alleged Pan-Islamic intrigues by the Sultan, who is by no means received everywhere in India as the representative of the Mohamedan world. The Indian Government has, however, hitherto rejected (and probably with wisdom) all attempts to set op an opposition in India to his religious headship."

div.head: NATIVES SEEK A WHITE LEADER.
div.p: "If ever there should happen to be a great European war, say between England and Germany, we would then have a rising in Africa," says Dr. Carl Peters, who has just returned from a visit to the Zambesi district. "The knowledge of the native population out there is increasing, and they are even now taking a keen interest in international politics. They already know the difference between the Powers and the various Governments.

Dr. Peters mentioned the following instance of the native unrest to a "Manchester Dispatch" representative :—During my last visit I was waited upon by a deputation from the people of Macombe, in Portuguese territory. They asked me if I would lead them if they rose against the Portuguese rule, and promised that, in the event of my consenting, they would appoint me their head chief, Naturally, I politely declined."

div.head: THE NATION OF HOTEL-KEEPERS.
div.p: The "Daily Chronicle's" Geneva correspondent calls attention to recent statistics which show that while the public wealth of Switzerland (State property excluded) has increased from ten milliards of francs to seventeen in half a century, two fifths of the increase is estimated to be the share of the hotel proprietors, who take in over £6,000,000 a year. Now, seventy per cent, of this, it is pointed out, comes from Anglo-Saxon visitors, and the correspondent observes that English people, finding it cheaper to stay in Switzerland than at home, now do so for months instead of weeks. It is certainly a fact that any one who has a month's holiday can more than make good the cost of the journey out and home, and spend the time at a Swiss mountain centre more cheaply than at an English seaside hotel—if he can resist the temptation to indulge in the costly delight of climbing. Of course, the Swiss hotel is at an advantage as compared with the English in that the cost of labour is much less, and it must be remembered that English visitors will cheerfully endure the scanty Continental "breakfast'' and sundry rough and ready details in a way that they would not at home. But even so, the management that makes such cheapness possible is worth the British caterer's study.

div.head: EGYPT AND GERMANY.
div.p: The "Standard" remarks:—

We regret to notice that some organs of German opinion are disposed to theorise about our attitude towards Egypt. To the ingenuity of learned professors who are unversed in practical affairs it is natural to fasten on technical anomalies, and to infer that Great Britain is forthwith resolved on regularising its position at Cairo. Because we are in sole occupation of the Khedive's dominions, and admit no other Power, not even Turkey, to a share in our reluctantly acquired responsibility, it is argued that we are scheming for the declaration of a Protectorate. On this point it may be as well to speak quite unreservedly. There is, we confess, one influence which would compel us to take the course which our critics deprecate by anticipation. If any attempt were made, directly or indirectly, to limit our practical authority or diminish our efficiency, we should feel ourselves bound to legitimate our supremacy. But we shall never accept or acquiesce in any modification of the existing status except such as would strengthen Lord Cromer's hands in dealing either with internal disturbance or external interference. This is not a matter on which we are open to negotiation or would listen to compromise. We might as well be invited to consider terms with regard to our command of the Channel as to enter into any arrangement that would imperil our main route to India. It has been said over and over again that Egypt is the Nile and the Nile is Egypt. Equally it is true that the Suez Canal is India, and India is the Suez Canal By no act or volition of ours we were drawn into the custody of that international waterway. In order to perform that onerous duty we have made heavy sacrifices, and we do not intend, under any conceivable conditions, to relax our hold on the Valley of the Nile. There was a time when in good faith we attempted to relieve ourselves of the honourable burden. But the repeated overtures made by Lord Salisbury were rejected. From that time onwards it has become the settled policy of Great Britain to maintain an adequate Army of Occupation, and to be prepared, at any moment, to support it with the whole force of the British Empire. Whatever negotiations may be proposed by Germany or any other Great Power, it may be taken as established that Egypt will not be used as a counter in the diplomatic game. On this fundamental question the Liberals are not less definite than the Conservatives. Lord Rosebery and Sir Edward Grey have proved themselves as immovable as their Unionist predecessors.

div.head: GERMAN FRIENDSHIP IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Edward Dicey, writing in the "Empire Review" on Islam in fermentation, traces the uprising of the natives in various parts of the French, German, and English colonies to the recent defeat of Russia by a non-European Power. This has stirred the Moslem feeling. Mr. Dicey entirely approves Lord Cromer's stern measures in the recent executions. He goes on to say this good and timely word for Germany :—

"To the best of my belief our own Government is fully aware how much we owe to the refusal of Germany to give any encouragement to the invasion of the Sinai Peninsula by Turkish troops. It is certain that if Germany had kept silent at Constantinople, the Sultan, relying on the supposed good-will of Germany and on the temporary effacement of Russia as a military Power, would have pursued his aggressive policy towards Egypt, and would have compelled England to engage in a war with Turkey, and by so doing expose herself to the bitter hostility of Islam throughout Asia and Africa generally, and especially in Egypt. We thus owe our escape from a position of grave embarrassment, which would, in all likelihood, have eventuated in war, to the good faith of Germany. This being so, commonsense, not to speak of common gratitude, should compel us to look with great scepticism upon all reports, emanating for the most part from French sources, which seek to represent Germany as being engaged in perpetual intrigues to undermine British influence in Africa and elsewhere. These reports are reproduced by a section of the British press without hostile comment, and their reproduction naturally creates an unfavourable impression on the German public."

div.head: CANNED MUSIC.
div.p: Mr. Sousa, the March King, has started a campaign against what he calls "canned music," meaning thereby all music produced by mechanical devices, such as one finds probably in the majority of American homes Machine music, he declares, is deteriorating the national taste and injuriously affecting teachers of legitimate music, who are finding it hard to make both ends meet. If the epidemic of machine music continues to spread at the present rate Mr. Sousa prophesies a day near at hand when the country bands which now delight the rural communities will be no more.

div.p: "I got caught in a shower at a picnic," said Miss Maggie Simpson, of Stirling Village, near Peterhead, Aberdeenshire, "and my dress was soaked by rain. That day's outing would have cost me my life had it not been for Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, which rescued me from a terrible illness and brought me back to health. After this soaking I caught a severe chill and, before long, the mischief had settled in my lungs. Acute pains seized me in my chest, and a bad cough made me expectorate quantities of blood. My state of health became serious, and for weeks I was kept in bed under medical treatment A doctor told my mother I was threatened with consumption, and as the chest pains increased so I continued to bring up more blood. Then I had to go into hospital, where I remained for six weeks; all this time I was frightfully emaciated and weak. Nothing gave me hope, and at length I was taken home again, where I lay for months an invalid.

"It was a sad time for my parents, who greatly feared they would lose me. One day mother asked me to try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, and though every other treatment had failed so utterly, I consented. I was surprised to find when I had taken these pills a little time that I felt stronger, and improved in health generally. I persevered, and then my longs healed, the coughing and bleeding stopped, and I began to pot on flesh. Then I found a healthy appetite and could digest food. Within three months no one would have recognized me—I was so completely altered and restored. My health and spirits are excellent now, and it is nearly a year since my cure was effected."

The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah, Zagazig, or Saida Zenah.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
